did.unittitle: Official register of Harvard University, 1900-2008
did.abstract: The Official Register of Harvard University is a set of publications that has been published annually by Harvard since 1900. While specific titles included within the register have varied over time, much of the content has remained consistent, including annual reports of the president and treasurer, course catalogs, announcements of departments and divisions, student handbooks, and directories.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Juliana Kuipers created this finding from February to June 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope Note
scopecontent.p: The Official Register of Harvard University is a set of publications that has been published annually by Harvard since 1900. While specific titles included within the register have varied over time, much of the content has remained consistent, including annual reports of the president and treasurer, course catalogs, announcements of departments and divisions, student handbooks, and directories.
The archivist has included information regarding missing or unpublished issues, when known, at the series level.
Since 2005, course catalog information has been available online.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological order by year of publication. Within each year, arranged by volume and issue number.
Duplicate copies are arranged in chronological order at the end of the finding aid.

relatedmaterial.head: Related material
relatedmaterial.p: The Harvard University Archives holds additional copies of many of the titles represented in the Official Register. These copies are cataloged individually by title in HOLLIS, Harvard's on-line library catalog.

unittitle.title: Harvard University, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, supplements to the general announcement,

scopecontent.head: Scope and content
scopecontent.p: Contains unnumbered supplements to the general announcement. Titles include Ph.D. in social science; higher degrees in philosophy; higher degrees in the classics; higher degrees in the history and philosophy of religion; degree of master in forestry; higher degrees in political science; higher degrees in engineering sciences and applied physics; housing, dining and parking facilities; higher degrees in physics; higher degrees in Celtic languages and literatures; higher degrees in music; higher degrees in anthropology; higher degrees in Romance lanuages and literatures; higher degrees in history; higher degrees in chemistry; higher degrees in the history and principles of the fine arts; and Ph.D. in the history of American civilization.
